The main objective of performing the offsite consequence analysis is to determine the distance at which certain effects might occur to the public because of an accidental release (called the endpoint distance).  The following effects could occur at the endpoint distance.  At distances less than the endpoint distance, the effects would be greater; at distances greater than the endpoint distance, the effects would be less.  When considering the release of a toxic substance, such as anhydrous ammonia, most people at the endpoint distance would be able to walk away from the exposure without any long-term health consequences, although some short-term consequences (e.g., strong eye or throat irritation) are likely.  The recommended response to a release is to shelter-in-place and to shut off any air intakes (e.g., air conditioners or fresh air make-up systems).

The RMP rule includes specific requirements for the worst-case and alternative release scenarios that must be reported by Conectiv.  These requirements are:

* One worst-case release scenario for each Program 1 process (the Bethlehem Plant does not have any processes meeting the Program 1 definition)
* One worst-case release scenario for the class of toxic substances in Program 3 processes (i.e., one scenario representing the anhydrous ammonia process)  
* One alternative release scenario for each of the toxic substances in a Program 3 process (i.e. one scenario representing the anhydrous ammonia process)
* One wors

t-case and one alternative release scenario for the class of flammable substances in Program 2 and Program 3 processes (the Bethlehem Plant does not have any process chemicals meeting the flammable substance definition)

The following information summarizes the offsite consequence analysis performed by Conectiv. 

1.3.1 Program 3 Processes - Toxic Substances

The worst-case release scenario for toxic substances is the instantaneous release of the entire contents of a 12,000 gal (56,000 pound) anhydrous ammonia storage tank in the Anhydrous Ammonia System. The solution evaporates and forms a vapor cloud. The Anhydrous Ammonia would be released to atmosphere over a 10-minute period. The scenario results in off-site impacts to both public and environmental receptors.  Each system was analyzed as a separate source due to the location and seperation of each system. 

Alternative Release Scenario 1 for the anhydrous ammonia system is a 3-inch hole in the storage tank.  Operators would be notified of a release by ammonia monitors located around the tank and throughout the process area.  The containment area would limit the extent of spread of the liquid ammonia and the water spray system would limit the vaporization of ammonia. Conservatively, 56,000 pounds of ammonia would be released from the time the incident began until it would all vaporize or be captured by the water spray system in an aqueous solution.  The scenario results in off-site impacts to both public and environmental receptors.

Alternate Release Scenario 2 for the anhydrous ammonia system is a tank failure that results in a release of liquid ammonia into the containment area.  The liquid ammonia slowly fumes off (rate reduced by the auto-refrigeration effect of evaporating ammonia).  The release scenario was modeled to represent the effects without the water spray system since the water would add heat to the system causing a further release.

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN
CONECTIV BETHLEHEM, LLC
BETHLEHEM, PENNSYLVANIA

1. Executive Summary 

Conectiv Bethlehem, LLC(Conectiv) is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for Conectiv workers, the public, and the environment. As a demonstration of that commitment, Conectiv has developed and implemented Environmental and Workplace Health and Safety Policies to serve as guiding principles for all it's employees and operations.  Conectiv believes that following these policies is the responsibility of every employee. 

As part of this commitment, Conectiv has established a system to help ensure safe operation of the processes at this facility.  One component of this system is a Risk Management Program (RMP) that helps manage the risks at Conectiv and that complies with the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) regulation 40 CFR part 68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs (the RMP rule).  One of the requirements of the RMP rule is to submit a risk management plan (RMP Plan) describing the risk management program at Conectiv.  This document is intended to satisfy the RMP Plan requirement of the RMP rule and to provide the public with a description of the risk management program at Conectiv.

The risk management program at Conectiv consists of three elements:

1. A hazard assessment to help understand the potential offsite consequences of hypothetical accidental releases and a history of accidents that have occurred during the last five years associated with the use of substances regulated by the RMP rule (regulated substances) - see topics 1.3 and 1.5

2. A prevention program to help maintain and safely operate the processes containing more than a threshold quantity of a regulated substance (covered processes) - see topic 1.4

3. An emergency response program to help respond to accidental releases of regulated substances from covered processes - see topic 1.6


Information further describing these elements

is provided in this RMP Plan.

Although the risk management program at Conectiv helps provide assurance that the facility is maintained and operated in a safe manner, it is only one component of the safety program at Conectiv.  In fact, Conectiv has a comprehensive safety program in place establishing various levels of safeguards against release of a hazardous substance and injuries/damage from a release of a hazardous substance.

Conectiv limits the use of hazardous substances.  Before using a hazardous substance at Conectiv, less hazardous alternatives are considered. Part of Conectiv's RMP compliance philosophy has been the reduction of the use of hazardous substances covered under this regulation. When a hazardous substance is used, Conectiv considers the potential for this substance to adversely affect Conectiv workers, the public, and the environment and takes steps to prevent any such effects.

Conectiv works to prevent releases of the hazardous substances used at the facility.  When a hazardous substance is used at Conectiv, the equipment is designed, built, operated, and maintained to reduce the likelihood of an accidental release.  Industry and government standards are adhered to in the design, construction, operation, and maintenance of the equipment.

Conectiv limits damage from a release, if such a release were to occur.  Conectiv trains workers to react quickly in the event of an accidental release, reducing the consequences if a release were to occur.  In addition, Conectiv works with the local fire department and with the local emergency planning committee (LEPC) to help ensure that injuries and/or environmental damage will be minimized if a release does occur.

The safety program at Conectiv consists of a number of elements, only some of which are required by the RMP rule.  This RMP Plan is primarily intended to describe those parts of the safety program at Conectiv that are required by the RMP rule.

Conectiv is committed to the safety of workers and the public, and the preservation of the environment, through the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances.  Conectiv implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous substances.  These controls include training programs for personnel; programs to help ensure safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of processes at Conectiv; and programs to evaluate the hazards at Conectiv.

In order to effectively implement these policies, Conectiv established a management system headed by the Plant's Operations and Maintenance Manager to oversee safety-related activities.


1.2 Conectiv and Regulated Substances

The Bethlehem Plant is a power generation facility designed to supply power during peak demand periods.  In order to support these operations, Conectiv handles regulated substances (anhydrous ammonia) in sufficient quantities to be covered by the RMP rule, as shown below.

The plant is designed in two identical power blocks.  Each block contains three combustion turbines, three heat recovery steam generators and one steam turbine generator.  Each block has its own anhydrous ammonia system to control NOx emissions from the combustion turbines.

1.3 Offsite Consequence Analysis

Conectiv performed an analysis of the potential offsite consequence for an accidental release of a regulated substance that could have on the public or the environment. The RMP regulations require that such an analysis include an evaluation of both worst-case release scenarios and alternative release scenarios.  Conectiv does not expect a worst-case release scenario to ever occur. However in accordance with the RMP requirements, a worst case release analysis was conducted and the results are reported in this document. 

The alternative release scenarios evaluated are intended to represent releases that might occur and were based on Conectiv's experience with ammonia systems. The alternative release scenarios were selected to help the local emergency planning committee (LEPC) improve community emergency response plans.  An alternative release scenario represents a release that (1) might occur at a facility like Conectiv's and (2) would result in the greatest potential offsite consequences if the release occurred.  While Conectiv believes that such releases are unlikely to occur at the Bethlehem facility, Conectiv has evaluated the offsite impact of the releases in accordance with the regulatory requirements.  Even though not required by regulation, Conectiv performed two alternate release scenarios.  

Conectiv has conducted the offsite consequence analysis for the worst-case release scenario using the EPA's guidance document and RMP*Comp that was developed to provide the highest estimate of the possible offsite consequences of such a release. The main objective of performing the offsite consequence analysis is to determine the distance at which certain effects might occur to the public because of an accidental release (called the endpoint distance).  The model was developed to provide information on the estimated distance to the toxic endpoint for a chemical of concern. Conectiv has not conducted a more detaile

d analysis of these scenarios because the potential for such releases is unlikely and because more refined analysis of such events will not provide additional information that would be useful.

While the model provides the required data to meet regulatory requirements, it does not provide detailed information on the travel time or concentration of the chemical in the plume.  Typical information input to the model to characterize a chemical release is:

* Physical State:  gas, liquid, aerosol, and multi-phased
* Release Type:  continuous, instantaneous, point (stack releases), and area (releases from a pool)
* Release Condition:  height, substrate type (concrete, soil), area and height of curbing, exit velocity, release diameter, and exit temperature
* Chemical Properties:  molecular weight, specific gravity, vapor pressure, density, latent heat, and other properties depending upon the model

In addition to the physical parameters that characterize a release, meteorological data is needed by the model to characterize the ambient release conditions.  Meteorological data is used in dispersion models to calculate the distance that the pollutant plume moves downwind and the concentration of the pollutant at any given time or distance.  The meteorological variables that affect the dispersion of a chemical release are as follows:

* Wind Speed and Direction: The wind speed is used to determine the plume dilution, plume transport, plume rise, evaporation rate, and magnitude of the concentration.  Wind direction defines the direction in which the plume travels.
* Temperature:  Temperature is used to calculate plume rise and evaporation rates.
* Atmospheric Pressure: is used to calculate gas and liquid release rates.
* Atmospheric Stability: Stability is an indication of atmospheric turbulence.  The turbulence is depended upon thermal (heating of the ground) and mechanical (surface roughness and wind speed) effects.  Turbulence also acts to dilute the plume and reduce concent

A team composed of personnel with engineering, process operating experience, maintenance, and a leader with process hazard analyses experience is assembled to analyze the hazards of the process.  Conectiv primarily uses the hazard and operability (HAZOP) technique, supplemented with checklists, to perform this analysis. 3. Operating Procedures: Conectiv operators, process engineers and supervisors work together to develop and maintain operating procedures to define how tasks related to process operations should be safely performed.  The operating procedures (1) are used to train employees and (2) serve as reference guides for appropriate actions to take during both normal operations and emergency operations.

Conectiv personnel develop and maintain operating procedures that cover all phases of operations, including initial startup, normal operations, normal shutdown, emergency shutdown, startup following a turnaround or emergency shutdown, and temporary operations.  The operating procedures are used both to help in operating the covered processes and as a training guide for both new and experienced operators.  Operating procedures are updated at least annually to ensure they reflect current operating conditions.


4. Training: The Plant trains workers to perform their assigned tasks safely and effectively. The Conectiv training program includes both initial and refresher training that covers (1) a general overview of the process, (2) the properties and hazards of the substances in the process, and (3) a detailed review of the process ope

rating procedures and safe work practices.  Oral reviews and on-the-job training are used to verify that an employee understands the process operation prior to job assignment.

The operators are consulted annually during operating procedure reviews to evaluate the effectiveness and need for additional training.  Recommendations from the operators are reviewed, and changes to the training program are implemented, as appropriate.

5. Mechanical Integrity:  Conectiv maintains the mechanical integrity of process equipment to help prevent equipment failures that could endanger workers, the public, or the environment.  This is accomplished by: (1) an inspection and testing program to help identify equipment deterioration and damage before the equipment fails, (2) a quality assurance program to help ensure that new and replacement equipment meet the design standards required for service in the covered processes and (3) utilizing personnel who are specially trained to maintain process equipment.  

6. Management of Change:  The Conectiv management of change program evaluates and approves all proposed changes to chemicals, equipment, and procedures for a covered process to help ensure that the change does not negatively affect safe operations. Process changes that are determined to be a replacement in kind (e.g., replacing a valve with an identical valve) are allowed without completing a management of change form.  All other changes must be reviewed through the full management of change program, to help ensure that inadvertent consequences of process changes are prevented, safety consequences of changes are addressed, affected process safety information and procedures are updated, and affected employees are notified of the changes.

7. Pre-startup Review:  Conectiv performs a safety review of a new or modified process before the process is placed into service to help ensure that the process is safe to operate.  This review confirms that an employee has completed the requisit

formation for the covered processes. 

11. Hot Work Permits:  Conectiv uses a hot work permit program to control spark- or flame-producing activities that could result in fires or explosions at the Bethlehem Plant. Conectiv reviewed OSHA's fire prevention and protection requirements in 29 CFR 1910.252(a) and created a Hot Work Permit Form to comply with these requirements.  Personnel performing hot work are required to have an approved permit prior to beginning their work.  Training in the use of the Hot Work Permit Form is included in the Conectiv safe work practices orientation.

12. Contractors:  Conectiv has established Contractor Safety and Health Guidelines to outline expectations related to contractor work at the Bethlehem Plant including work on the covered process.  The program reviews the safety record of all contractors to help ensure that Conectiv only hires contractors who can safely perform the desired job tasks.  Conectiv explains to the contract supervisors the hazards of the process on which they and their employees will work, Conectiv safe work practices, and Conectiv emergency response procedures.  Conectiv requires that the contractor supervisors also train each of their employees prior to beginning their work on a covered process.  Conectiv periodically reviews contractors' training documents and work performance to help ensure that safe practices are followed. 


1.4.2  Program 2 Prevention Program

The Bethlehem Plant has no processes that qualify for the Program 2 Prevention Program.

1.4.3 Chemical-specific Prevention Steps

In addition to the required prevention program elements, Conectiv has implemented safety features specific to the hazardous substances used at the Bethlehem Plant.  The anhydrous ammonia system has been designed to handle anhydrous ammonia.  Conectiv compared anhydrous and aqueous ammonia and determined that anhydrous ammonia was more appropriate to minimize the potential for serious incident or off-site impact due to th

e following:

* decrease in the number of deliveries to the site; therefore less truck traffic;
* decrease in the number of delivery truck hook-ups and disconnects which is when the majority of all Ammonia releases occur; and
* decrease in the number of failure points (i.e., valves, pumps, flanges, etc.). 
* decrease in the likelihood of corrosion to the system due to the nature of Anhydrous Ammonia.

The process is located almost entirely within the containment area, which further reduces the hazard.  The storage tank is engineered specifically for anhydrous ammonia service.  The piping is double-contained, wrapped with corrosion protection tape, cathodically protected, and the interstitial space is charge with nitrogen and monitored.   The process uses an advanced control system with emergency shutdowns to ensure safe operation.   Detectors and alarms located around the tank, injection skids, and Heat Recovery Steam Generators provide continuous monitoring for ammonia in the event of a release, providing early detection and helping to ensure quick response if an incident were to occur.


1.5 Five-Year Accident History

Conectiv is required to complete a review of the covered process for incidents occurring in the five-year period prior to the submittal date for the regulation.  Since the system is new, there have been no incidents involving the regulated processes that have resulted in on-site or off-site impacts.  


1.6 Emergency Response Programs

Conectiv has established a written emergency response program to help safely respond to accidental releases of hazardous substances.  Conectiv does not have First Responder capabilities.  Conectiv's response will be to notify the City of Bethlehem and The Northampton County LEPC and other off-site emergency response personnel in the event of serious incident or off-site impact.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for:

* informing the LEPC about accidental releases that could reasonably result in offsit

e consequences.
* clear identification of communication, roles and responsibilities during an emergency event.
* reviewing and updating the emergency response plan.
 
All Conectiv personnel are trained in shelter-in-place and evacuation procedures.  Conectiv periodically coordinates emergency response drills.  The written emergency response plan complies with other federal contingency plan regulations (e.g., the OSHA regulations 29 CFR 1910.38(a), 29 CFR 1910.120(a)) and has been communicated to local emergency response officials and local fire departments.  Conectiv maintains a regular dialogue with the local fire officials and provides response information, as appropriate. 


1.7 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The Bethlehem Plant constantly strives to improve the safety of the regulated processes by following recommended safe practices, soliciting safety suggestions from employees, conducting hazard analysis studies and investigating process incidents.  The original HAZOP study provided design changes that are being incorporated into the final system design and construction.  Conectiv will continue to review and improve the safety of the anhydrous ammonia System.
